Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Document and report research findings accurately
Situation2: Routine logs are updated on a flexible schedule, and this batch of results could be recorded later without issue.
Story: I stared at my phone, reading my sister’s text: “Come to dinner with us tonight? Haven’t seen you in ages.” I could almost hear her voice, warm and hopeful, and I knew how much she valued these little gatherings. We’d promised to make more time for each other, to build the kind of relationship where we didn’t just pass like ships in the night. But my laptop screen glowed with the day’s data, waiting to be logged. The results weren’t urgent—my lab manager had said the logs could wait until tomorrow—but I prided myself on accuracy and consistency. If I let this slide, would it become a habit? Yet if I said no to my sister again, would she stop asking? My chest tightened as I weighed the pull of my work against the promise I’d made to her, feeling the two parts of myself tugging in opposite directions.
